questions.text: Erythema infectiosum is caused by:
questions.solution:
Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19.

It evolves in three phases:

  1. First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks, (slapped cheek). Prodromal symptoms may occur.
  2. Second phase -  begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk. The rash is more prominent on extensor surfaces and spares the palms and soles. At this stage, affected children are afebrile and do not appear ill.  Children with erythema infectiosum are not likely to be infectious at presentation.
  3. Third phase - Recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise.

Complications of the disease include:

  • Arthralgias or arthritis
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis: A transient arrest of erythropoiesis and absolute reticulocytopenia in serum hemoglobin in individuals with chronic hemolytic conditions like sickle cell anemia
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Myocarditis
  • A papular-purpuric “gloves-and-socks” syndrome
  • Neurological: Aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, and peripheral neuropathy, stroke in children with sickle cell disease
  • Infection-associated hemophagocytic syndrome in immunocompromised patients
  • Maternal infection is associated with nonimmune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise

Only about 7% of children with erythema infectiosum have arthralgias, whereas 80% of adults have joint involvement.

There is no data to support the use of IVIG for postexposure prophylaxis, however, it has been used with some success to treat B19-related episodes of anemia and bone marrow failure in immunocompromised children. There is no specific antiviral therapy for B19 infection.

Other options:

Option B: Human herpesvirus 6A causes roseola infantum.

Option C: Group A streptococcus causes scarlet fever.

Option D: Rubella virus causes rubella and congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: Thyroid masses move with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
Thyroid masses moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

  • The investing layer which splits to enclose the parotid and submandibular gland. It also forms the roof of the posterior triangle.
  • The pretracheal layer which encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either sides forms suspensory ligament which is known as ligament of Berry.
  • The carotid sheath which is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses the common and internal carotid arteries, internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.
  • The prevertebral fascia which forms the axillary sheath.
  • Buccopharyngeal fascia
  • Pharyngobasilar fascia

questions.text: A child with fever and rash present with the findings as shown in the image given below. What is the period of communicability of this disease?

choices.text: 4 days before and 2 days after the appearance of rash
2 days before and 2 days after the disappearance of rash
4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash
2 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

questions.solution:
The given image shows Koplik spots, which are a pathognomonic sign of measles. The period of communicability for measles is 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash. The patient is isolated for 1 week from the onset of rash. 

Measles is caused by the measles virus from the paramyxoviridae family. The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days. The clinical features are mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. The Koplik spots are red lesions with bluish-white spots seen in the inner cheeks at the level of premolars. The red maculopapular rashes begin on the forehead, behind the ears, and on the upper neck on the 4th day. It then spreads towards the torso, and extremities and reaches the palms and soles.

The diagnosis is mainly made clinically but a serological demonstration of IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies is also used. Complications are pneumonia, croup, tracheitis, etc. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Measles can be prevented by active immunization. Live attenuated vaccine is given subcutaneously except for immunocompromised and pregnant women. According to WHO it requires at least 96% immunization coverage under one year of age for eradication.

questions.text: Which pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor causes recurrent episodes of secretory diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumours (VIPomas) are pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) and cause recurrent episodes of secretory diarrhea. 

The condition is known as Verner–Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome.

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhoea.

Treatment includes correction of dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte losses with fluid and electrolyte replacement. Long-acting somatostatin analogues such as octreotide and lanreotide are the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the OPD. His parents describe that the boy had an episode of abnormal jerking movements that started in his left hand and gradually involved the entire arm. Following this, the patient experienced weakness and difficulty in moving the left arm for about an hour. Two similar episodes have also occurred in the past. His father is a known case of epilepsy. questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Jacksonian march followed by Todd’s palsy. These are characteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures is carbamazepine which is a sodium-channel blocker.

  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Carbamazepine

Carbamazepine is most effective in complex partial seizures. It is also used in GTCS and simple partial seizures, trigeminal and related neuralgias, manic depressive psychosis.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). questions.text: Primary active transport is mediated by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
The primary active transport is mediated by Na+-K+ ATPase.

In active transport, the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence active transport is mediated by ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP.

Carrier proteins can mediate both primary and secondary active transports while the Na/K-ATPase is a primary active transport protein.

PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT
Requires direct input of metabolic energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)   The transport of two or more solutes is coupled and metabolic energy is provided  indirectly from the Na+ gradient that is maintained across cell membranes by the Na+-K+-ATPase pump

a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium-potassium pump

b) Ca2+-ATPase

c) H+-ATPase (proton pump)

d) H+-K+-ATPase

a) Na+- glucose cotransport (SGLT)

b) Na+-Ca2+ counter transport

Other options :

Option A: G-proteins are molecular switches inside cells that transmit signals from receptors to trigger cellular responses. They play a crucial role in processes like hormone signalling, sensory perception, and cell growth.

Option C: Carrier proteins are membrane proteins that transport specific molecules across cell membranes by binding to them and undergoing conformational changes. They facilitate the movement of substances like ions, glucose, and amino acids into or out of cells.

Option D: Channel proteins are membrane proteins that form pores, allowing the passive movement of specific ions or molecules across the cell membrane. They facilitate processes like ion flow in nerve cells and water transport in kidney cells.

questions.text: The kidney shown in the photograph below exhibits a tumor that originated in the lower pole. Histologic sections from this lesion would most likely reveal______.

choices.text: Small cells with high N/C ratio

questions.solution:
The gross appearance of a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the pole is suggestive of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Clear-cell RCC is the most common type of RCC.  Microscopically, cells have a distinctive nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio where cells have abundant clear cytoplasm due to high lipid and glycogen content. Network of small, thin-walled blood vessels. Round to oval nuclei are present that are centrally located. May show varying degrees of pleomorphism. Tumor grade depends on nuclear features and arrangement.

Tumour may arise in any part of the kidney, but more commonly affects the poles. The distinctive yellow color and variegated appearance, combined with the polar location, are often key diagnostic features that help distinguish clear-cell RCC from other renal tumors during gross examination.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is receiving massive blood transfusion following fall from height. Within 4 hours of the last transfusion, he becomes breathless and oxygen saturation decreases. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral lung infiltrates. All the following statements are true regarding the condition, except that ______

choices.text: It is more common with multipara donors
It is mediated by macrophages in lung vasculature

questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is most likely to be TRALI (Transfusion-related acute lung injury) and it is not mediated by macrophages but by neutrophils entrapped in the lung vasculature.

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a severe, frequently fatal, complication in which factors in a transfused blood product trigger the activation of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature. The most common antibodies associated with TRALI are those that bind major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens, particularly MHC class I antigens(Option A).

These antibodies are often found in multiparous women (Option C), who generate such antibodies in response to foreign MHC antigens expressed by the fetus. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates that do not respond to diuretics are seen on chest imaging. Other associated findings include fever, hypotension, and hypoxemia. Mortality is 5% in uncomplicated cases(Option B) and up to 67% in those who are severely ill.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man who presented with burning pain in lower extremities along with staggering gait was diagnosed with burning feet syndrome. On further evaluation, he was found to be deficient in a particular vitamin. The deficient vitamin contains which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that is deficient in burning feet syndrome (nutritional melalgia) is vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) which contains beta-alanine.

The burning sensation in burning feet syndrome (nutritional melalgia) typically follows a characteristic pattern with intense burning pain in both feet. It may begin in soles and spread upward can progress from feet to ankles and eventually calves. Heat sensation may persist even when feet feel physically cold. It exhibits a nocturnal pattern wherein the symptoms are significantly worse at night.

Beta-alanine is seen in:

  • Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5): As a structural component.
  • Coenzyme A: Derived from pantothenic acid, essential for fatty acid metabolism and many other biochemical reactions.
  • Carnosine: A dipeptide of beta-alanine and histidine, found in muscle tissue.
  • Anserine: A methylated form of carnosine found in skeletal muscle.
  • Acyl Carrier Protein (ACP): A component of fatty acid synthesis complex containing a pantetheine prosthetic group.

Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency are GI disturbances, Paraesthesia, Muscle cramps, Ataxia, Fatigue, Poor wound healing and Sleep disturbances.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to produce the following adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine is the drug that most likely produces the adverse effect shown in the image above, gum hyperplasia. 

Other drugs that cause gum hyperplasia are:

  • Phenytoin
  • Calcium channel blockers

Cyclosporine is an immunomodulator that binds with the cyclophilin protein and this complex inhibits the calcineurin activity. It decreases the T-cell activation and is useful in T-cell mediated transplant rejection. It is useful in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, uveitis, Behcet's disease, atopic dermatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, nephrotic syndrome, etc. The major adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hirsutism
  • Gum hyperplasia
  • Nephrotoxicity
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Altered mental status, seizures

Other options:

Option A- Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic agent used in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, focal seizures, trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias, bipolar disorder, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The main adverse events are hepatotoxicity, dilutional hyponatremia, hypersensitivity reactions, aplastic anemia, and agranulocytosis.

Option B- Tacrolimus is a macrolide antibiotic that binds to FKBP-12 protein (similar to cyclophilin) and inhibits calcineurin activity. It is indicated in the prophylaxis of solid-organ allograft rejection. Some of the adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, hypertension, and hyperglycemia.

Option D- Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic agent used in focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures and Lennox Gestaut syndrome. The adverse effects include Stevens-Johnson syndrome, dizziness, ataxia, and double vision.

questions.text: Which of the following heart tumours exhibit the histologic pattern as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells. They are seen in Rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing often artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane, an appearance referred to as “spider” cells.

 Rhabdomyoma is the most frequent primary tumour of the pediatric heart. 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tumour-suppressor genes TSC1 and TSC2. Usually multiple and prefer ventricles preferentially. Often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas.

The image below shows the spider cell in rhabdomyoma.

Other options:

Option A: Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. They are benign, unlike rhabdomyoma, and single. The common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Option B: Papillary fibroelastoma is a rare, benign cardiac tumour that typically arises on heart valves, most commonly the aortic or mitral valve. It can lead to embolism, stroke, or valve dysfunction, often discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Option D: Cardiac rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor of the heart, arising from striated muscle cells. It commonly presents with heart failure, arrhythmias, or obstructive symptoms due to rapid growth and invasion of cardiac structures.

questions.text: An intellectually challenged teenager was diagnosed with a trinucleotide repeat mutation disease. On examination, his IQ is 49. He has a long face with a large mandible, everted large ears, a high-arched palate, and large testicles. What is the most likely nucleotide repeat sequence in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of fragile X syndrome. The specific trinucleotide repeat sequence in fragile X syndrome is CGG.

Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after Down's syndrome. It is due to the mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1) located on the long arm of the X chromosome. 

It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family. The affected males are intellectually disabled, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60. Neuropsychiatric features include aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism (large testicles)
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

Other options:

Option A: CAG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Huntington’s disease, spinocerebellar ataxia 1,2,3,6,7 and spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

Option B: CTG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in myotonic dystrophy.

Option D: GAA is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Friedreich ataxia.

questions.text: A patient presents with a wound on his leg. It heals six weeks later. Which of the following mediators is involved in promoting wound healing?
questions.solution:
TGF β (Transforming growth factor β) was responsible for the wound healing. It inhibits T- and B-cell proliferation. It acts as a growth factor for fibroblasts and also promotes class switching of B cells to IgA. TGF β is produced by T and B cells. 

Other options:

Option B: Interferon-alpha (IFN-α) is a cytokine produced by white blood cells that helps the body fight viral infections and modulate the immune response. It is used therapeutically to treat conditions like hepatitis B and C, and certain cancers.

Option C: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in immune responses, inflammation, and apoptosis. It plays a key role in autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and is a target for biological therapies.

Option D: Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a cytokine that modulates the immune response, primarily used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis (MS) to reduce inflammation and immune attacks on the nervous system. It has antiviral properties and enhances the activity of immune cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of synthesis of fatty acids is correct?

choices.text: Acetyl-CoA serves as the primary and essential donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.
Malonyl-CoA is the most active donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.
Fatty acid synthesis is the reverse of  oxidation of fatty acids.
Coenzyme A is the acyl group carrier of intermediates in fatty acid synthesis.

questions.solution:
The correct statement about the mechanism of synthesis of fatty acids is that Malonyl-CoA is the most active donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.

Malonyl-CoA is a 3-carbon unit that donates 2-carbon units in fatty acid synthesis. It is formed from acetyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase. During fatty acid synthesis, acetyl CoA primarily acts as the primer. The enzyme fatty acid synthase (FAS) adds two carbons from malonyl-CoA to the initial acetyl-CoA, forming a 4-carbon intermediate (butyryl-ACP). FAS then sequentially adds two carbons from malonyl-CoA to the ACP-intermediates (eg: butyryl-ACP) to elongate the fatty acid chain. 

Thus, in the end product palmitic acid (C16), only carbon atoms 15 and 16 are from acetyl CoA (Option A). The remaining 14 carbon atoms are derived from malonyl-CoA. Thus, malonyl-CoA is the most active donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.

Other options:

Option C: Fatty acid synthesis is not a simple reversal of oxidation of fatty acids. These two processes involve completely different enzymes and occur in different compartments of the cell. 

Option D: Intermediates in fatty acid synthesis are covalently linked to the sulfhydryl group of an acyl carrier protein (ACP), not coenzyme A, of the enzyme fatty acid synthase. Intermediates in the fatty acid breakdown are covalently attached to the sulfhydryl group of coenzyme A.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario the diagnosis is Familial hypercholesterolemia.

Familial hypercholesterolemia  (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) include painful polyarthritis and tendinitis. Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with, LDL > 190 mg/dl, family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or premature coronary artery disease. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients. Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively.

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text: The type of perversion where a person wears the clothes of opposite sex is:
questions.solution:
The type of perversion where a person wears the clothes of the opposite sex is called as fetishistic transvestism.

Fetishistic transvestism is a paraphilia characterised by recurrent sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges, or behaviour involving the wearing of clothes of the opposite sex and appearing as a member of the opposite sex. Also called transvestic fetishism. Usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality.

Option A: Transsexualism is a perversion where there is an obsessional desire to become members of the opposite sex and seek surgery for anatomical alterations.

Option C: Frotteurism is a condition where a person obtains sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs etc. in crowds etc). It is punishable under Section 290 IPC, with a fine of up to 200 Rs.

Option D: Exhibitionism involves behaviours over a period of 6 months or more, involving the exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. This is a punishable offence (Section 294 IPC) with imprisonment of up to 3 months or a fine.

NOTE- According to standard psychiatry books, transvestism is a gender identity disorder whereas fetishistic transvestism is a paraphilia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding excitation-contraction coupling in smooth muscle?

choices.text: Sustained contraction occurs with high calcium concentration
Phosphorylation of actin is required for contraction
Cellular calcium concentration is essential to cause contraction

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding excitation-contraction coupling in smooth muscle is cellular calcium concentration is essential to cause contraction.

Excitation-contraction coupling is the process by which an electrical impulse (action potential) triggers muscle contraction. This involves the transmission of the action potential along the muscle fibre membrane, leading to the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which then interacts with the actin and myosin filaments to produce muscle contraction. Increased cytosolic Ca2+ is essential for the contraction of smooth muscles.

Events in Excitation Contraction Coupling in Smooth Muscles:

A unitary smooth muscle is unique in that it can contract when stretched even in the absence of any extrinsic innervation. Stretch is followed by a decrease in membrane potential and an increase in the tone of the muscle.

Other options:

Option a: Troponin is absent in smooth muscle.

Option b: Sustained contraction of the smooth muscle occurs even when the calcium concentration falls. This is mainly because of the latch-bridge mechanism where the myosin cross-bridges remain attached to the actin. This mechanism allows for maintaining the contraction with less expenditure of energy and is particularly important in the vascular smooth muscle.

Option c: Unlike skeletal muscle where troponin binding is essential for contraction, smooth muscle contraction requires phosphorylation of myosin (not actin).

In the iceberg of disease, diagnosed cases under treatment do not represent the submerged portion of the iceberg.

The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The water surface is the line of demarcation between the apparent and inapparent infections. The iceberg phenomenon is shown by polio, influenza, rubella, mumps, Japanese Encephalitis, diphtheria, hepatitis A and B, tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition and hypertension.

questions.text: If a fetus is born dead at 6 months, which of the following cannot be a possible finding during the autopsy?
questions.solution:
Adipocere formation cannot be an autopsy finding in the given scenario since fetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

Adipocere is the formation of a soft greyish-white, waxy, greasy material with an offensive, sweet rancid smell, occurring in fatty tissues due to postmortem hydrolysis or hydrogenation of the fats. It is a modification of Putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environments. Fetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

Other options:

Option A and C: If the pregnancy with the dead fetus continues, it may be gradually mummified or resorbed. 

Option C: The most important post-mortem change in an intrauterine death is maceration, which is an autolytic process by which there is self-disintegration of the body by cellular enzymes. This can occur if the death of the fetus happens days to months before the delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following tools of recombinant DNA technology is incorrectly paired with its use?

choices.text: DNA polymerase - copies DNA sequences in the polymerase chain reaction
DNA ligase - enzyme that cuts DNA, creating sticky ends
Reverse transcriptase - production of cDNA from mRNA

questions.solution:
The incorrectly paired option is "DNA ligase is an enzyme that cuts DNA, creating sticky ends." Because DNA ligase joins adjacent nucleotides in a covalent linkage.

DNA ligase is an essential enzyme involved in DNA repair and replication processes. It facilitates the joining of DNA strands by catalyzing the formation of phosphodiester bonds between the 3'-hydroxyl and 5'-phosphate ends of adjacent nucleotides. This action is crucial during DNA replication, where it seals the nicks between Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand, and in DNA repair processes, such as base excision repair and double-strand break repair. DNA ligase is also involved in various genetic recombination events, making it vital for maintaining the integrity and stability of the genome.

Restriction enzymes, also known as restriction endonucleases, are specialized enzymes that recognize and cut DNA at specific sequences, typically 4-8 base pairs in length. The recognition sequences these enzymes target are usually palindromic, meaning they read the same on both DNA strands when read in the 5' to 3' direction. When restriction enzymes cut DNA, they can create either blunt ends (straight cuts) or sticky/cohesive ends (staggered cuts that leave single-stranded overhangs), which are crucial for various molecular cloning techniques.

Other options:

Option A: DNA polymerase is crucial in PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) as it amplifies specific DNA sequences by synthesizing new strands during repeated cycles of denaturation, annealing, and extension. The heat-stable Taq polymerase is commonly used in PCR to withstand the high temperatures required for denaturation.

Option C: Reverse transcriptase is an enzyme that synthesizes complementary DNA (cDNA) from an RNA template during reverse transcription. It is essential in the replication of retroviruses and is widely used in molecular biology techniques like cDNA synthesis and cloning.

Option D: Electrophoresis - RFLP (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism) analysis is a molecular technique that uses restriction enzymes to cut DNA at specific sequences, generating fragments of varying lengths. These fragments are then separated by gel electrophoresis, allowing for the detection of genetic variations or mutations.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate is brought with failure to pass meconium since birth. The baby's abdomen is markedly distended and he aspirates on feeding. Rectal suction biopsy shows a lot of hypertrophied nerve bundles with increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of failure to pass meconium and a markedly distended abdomen along with a biopsy showing aganglionosis suggests a likely diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease/congenital aganglionic megacolon.

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder of the enteric nervous system. Normally, the enteric neuronal plexus develops by neural crest cells migrating to the colon wall. When there is a mutation in tyrosine kinase receptor RET, it results in premature arrest of this regular migration from the cecum to the rectum. This results in the lack of Auerbach and Meissner submucosal plexus in the distal intestinal segment (aganglionosis) causing hypertonicity of the bowel wall. Thus, there is a functional obstruction in the distal segment that also results in massive dilatation of the proximal segment (megacolon). 

      Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The onset of constipation can be seen at birth. Patients present with intermittent attacks of fever and pain due to intestinal obstruction from the retained feces. Complications include enterocolitis and bowel perforation. 

A rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and shows increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. Other investigations include anorectal manometry and barium contrast enema. 

Surgical intervention is the only definitive treatment available.

Other options:

Option B: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis generally presents as new-onset regurgitation and projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A firm abdominal mass and abnormal left-to-right hyperperistalsis can be seen. Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography. 

Option C: Wilkie syndrome, otherwise known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome, occurs due to the compression of the third duodenal segment against the aorta by this artery. Diagnosis is by radiological demonstration of duodenal cutoff along with proximal duodenal dilatation. 

Option D: Functional constipation, otherwise known as fecal withholding, is the intentional or subconscious withholding of stool. It usually starts after the neonatal period. Here daytime encopresis (passage of stools at inappropriate places after 4 years of age) is common.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following glycolytic enzymes leads to hemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
Hemolytic anaemia is caused due to a deficiency of the enzyme pyruvate kinase.

Erythrocytes lack mitochondria and hence generate ATP exclusively via glycolysis. In a glycolytic enzyme deficiency, there is a reduced rate of glycolysis, leading to decreased ATP production. This results in a few alterations in the RBC membrane, thereby leading to changes in cell shape. Such deformed RBCs are later phagocytosed by cells of the reticuloendothelial system, and this results in a state of hemolytic anaemia.

The most common enzyme deficiency causing hemolytic anaemia is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (pentose phosphate pathway). The second most common enzyme deficiency causing hemolytic anaemia is the pyruvate kinase.

Note: Though hemolysis is seen in PFK-1 deficiency, it does not always manifest as anaemia.

Other options:

Option A: Enolase is a glycolytic enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate in glycolysis. It also serves as a marker in diseases like neuroendocrine tumours (e.g., NSE in small-cell lung cancer).

Option C: Aconitase is an enzyme in the TCA cycle that catalyzes the reversible isomerization of citrate to isocitrate via cis-aconitate. It also functions as an iron-sulfur protein and plays a role in cellular iron regulation.

Option D: Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is a key rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis that catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. It is tightly regulated by ATP, AMP, and citrate levels to control glycolytic flux.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions in a child would not be associated with a head circumference <3 SD below the mean for age and sex?

Standard deviation- SD
questions.solution:
Of the conditions listed, achondroplasia is not linked to microcephaly, which is defined as a head circumference below 3 SD from the mean for age and sex, whereas all other conditions are associated with it.

Head circumference in a child is measured as the maximum circumference from the external occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges and is one of the important anthropometric measurements in the assessment of growth and development. Based on this:

  • Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference <3 SD below the mean for age and sex.
  • Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference >2 SD above the mean for age and sex.

  • Neural tube defects
  • Perinatal Insult: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, hypoglycemia
  • Metabolic disorders: Phenylketonuria, methylmalonic aciduria, citrullinemia

  • Maternal teratogens like alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, cocine, antiepileptics
  • Endocrine causes: Hypothyroidism, hypopituitarism, adrenal insufficiency
  • Craniosynostosis

  • Bone disease like achondroplasia, osteogenesis imperfecta, osteopetrosis

questions.text: Which of the following disability indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
DALY(Disability Adjusted Life Years) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

Disability Adjusted Life Years: Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD).

It can measure both mortality and disability together. Alzheimer's Disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age due to which the YLL will be lower than other diseases that develop in a younger age group. Generally, Road Traffic Accidents would be considered to have a high DALY as it is more prevalent in the younger age group and thus the YLL will be higher.

Other options:

Option A: Sullivan’s Index is a measure used in epidemiology to assess the impact of a disease on a population’s life expectancy by considering both mortality and morbidity. It quantifies the number of years lost due to ill health or disability.

Option C: Work loss days refer to the number of days an individual is unable to work due to illness, injury, or disability. It is commonly used in health economics to assess the productivity loss and economic burden of diseases.

Option D: Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure used to assess the impact of premature death by calculating the years lost before a person reaches a predetermined age, often 75. It helps highlight the effect of early mortality on a population's overall health.

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. Histopathology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of thorn prick injury, warty, verrucous growth and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies suggest chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis, the most common chromomycosis, is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection.

Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. The disease generally remains localised with slow peripheral extension. Lymphatic spread can occur.

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous, and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

Other options:

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate is being evaluated for failure to thrive, excessive vomiting, abdominal distention, and steatorrhea.  Abdominal CT reveals hepatosplenomegaly and calcified adrenals bilaterally. Further investigation reveals a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, intractable vomiting, steatorrhea, and bilateral adrenal calcification points towards a probable diagnosis of Wolman disease.

Wolman disease is a rare disorder that results from a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). This leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs, leading to organomegaly as in this case. Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

LAL deficiency can present in two forms- Wolman disease and cholesterol ester storage disease. Cholesterol ester storage disease is less severe and usually presents late in adulthood, whereas Wolman disease presents within the first few weeks of life and results in death within the first 6 months of life. 

Wolman disease can be diagnosed by measuring LAL activity in peripheral leukocytes or cultured skin fibroblasts. Treatment is with a recombinant form of LAL. Those treated have been seen to survive beyond one year of age.

Other options-

Option (A): Krabbe disease is also a fatal disease of early infancy but it occurs due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactocerebrosidase and hence, the accumulation of galactosylceramide in the white matter of the brain.

Option (B): Farber disease results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme acid ceramidase. Thus, ceramide accumulates in various tissues, especially the joints. Symptoms include painful joint swelling and nodule formation, resembling rheumatoid arthritis within the first year of life.

Option (D): Gaucher disease is one of the most common lysosomal storage disorders. It occurs due to a deficiency of acid β-glucosidase. It presents most commonly with organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures. It is most prevalent among Ashkenazi Jews.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma comes for her chemotherapy treatment. She has had multiple complaints of nausea and vomiting during her previous treatment visits. Which of the following is used to prevent chemotherapy-induced emesis and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Palonosetron is used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Palonosetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist that blocks serotonin in vagal terminals and centrally in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ). It has a higher receptor affinity as compared to the first-generation 5HT3 antagonists making it more potent. It is also useful in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy due to its long half-life. 

During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT(serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. The released serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors and activates the vagal afferents in the gut that carry the emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. The selective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulses.

It is used in combination with netupitant in acute and delayed nausea and vomiting. Netupitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist. It augments the effects of palonosetron. This combination is particularly anti-emetogenic when given along with dexamethasone.

Other options:

Option A: Metoclopramide is a 5HT4 agonist and D2 blocker and is used as an antiemetic agent.

Option B: Ropinirole is an antiparkinsonian drug that is a dopamine agonist and is also the drug of choice for restless leg syndrome.

Option C: Domperidone is not used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: What ECG change is associated with the use of the anti-tubercular drug Bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Bedaquiline is associated with a prolonged QT interval.

Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB. Bedaquiline is a bactericidal drug that belongs to diarylquinolines. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme ATP synthase in the Mycobacterium. 

Bedaquiline is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism. It is largely deposited in tissues owing to its amphiphilicity. Resistance caused by mutations in efflux pumps and their regulators is also observed and is linked to the development of cross-resistance to clofazimine.

CYP3A4 is a major enzyme involved in the metabolism of bedaquiline.

Due to the high risk of QT prolongation, the FDA has issued a black box warning against the use of bedaquiline therefore having restricted use in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities.

questions.text: According to the myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch induced by______
questions.solution:
The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch induced by the opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called Myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. 

The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance.

This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced injury.

Autoregulation has two main mechanisms:

  • Metabolic mechanism: Tissues produce vasodilatory metabolites that regulate flow e.g., adenosine, prostaglandins, NO, CO2, H+ and K+
  • Myogenic mechanism: The myogenic mechanism is a process by which blood vessels, particularly arterioles, regulate their own blood flow in response to changes in blood pressure. When blood pressure increases, the smooth muscle in the blood vessel wall is stretched, triggering a reflex contraction (vasoconstriction) to prevent excessive blood flow. Conversely, when blood pressure decreases, the smooth muscle relaxes (vasodilation) to allow for increased blood flow. This mechanism helps maintain stable blood flow to tissues and organs despite fluctuations in systemic blood pressure.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated multiple long bone fractures. On examination, there is the presence of blue sclera and dental abnormalities. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated multiple bone fractures, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta(or brittle bone disease) is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to abnormal type 1 collagen production. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

The main features are joints that are vulnerable to fracture (joint laxity), scleral alterations(blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness. Multiple bone fractures are a consequence of bone fragility. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones with various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed. Management comprises the use of bisphosphonates, along with physiotherapy and walking aids.

Option A: Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia with disproportionately short limbs, sleep apnea, and kyphoscoliosis. Facial features include button nose, frontal bossing, macrocephaly, etc.

(a) Prominent forehead and body asymmetry, (b) a low nasal bridge, (c) trident hands, (d) scoliosis 

Option C: Cretinism occurs due to iodine deficiency. Its clinical features are deaf-mutism, squint, mental retardation, and spastic or rigid neuromotor disorder. 

Option D: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder. The affected persons will be tall with long limbs and digits. Spontaneous pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and lens dislocation are also seen. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation.

questions.text: A tourist with a travel history to India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a tourist with abdominal pain, and multiple episodes of diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is suggestive of the traveller’s diarrhea, most commonly caused by Enterotoxigenic E.Coli. The antidiarrheal agent used in the given scenario is loperamide. 

Loperamide is generally indicated in non-infective diarrhea, but it is also given as an anti-diarrheal agent in traveller's diarrhea in addition to antibiotics.

It is an opioid receptor agonist and slows intestinal motility by direct effects on the circular and longitudinal muscles. It reduces fecal volume and increases viscosity. It is used in traveller's diarrhea for symptomatic treatment in conjunction with antibiotics. It is avoided in patients with dysentery. 

Other options: 

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveller's diarrhea. 

Option C: Rifaximin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of traveller's diarrhea. It is an alternative to Azithromycin due to poor absorption. 

Option D: Bismuth subsalicylate is an over-the-counter (OTC) preparation used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is used in the treatment of traveller's diarrhea but is not preferred over loperamide due to a requirement for large doses, and salicylate toxicity, especially in high-risk groups (pregnancy, children, and individuals who take aspirin).

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidneys?
questions.solution:

The kidney develops from 3 sources as follows:

  • Metanephric blastema (Option C) gives rise to the excretory system of the kidney. It forms the Bowman's capsule, the proximal convoluted tubule, the loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule.

  • Angiogenic mesenchyme (Option A), which migrates into the metanephric blastema, gives rise to the glomeruli and the vasa recta.

questions.text: The study of heritable changes in gene expression that are not caused by alterations in DNA sequence is called ______.
questions.solution:
Epigenetics deals with the study of heritable changes in gene function, not involving changes in the DNA sequence.

The term “epigenetics” means “above genetics.” It refers to the regulatory mechanisms that do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather change the expression patterns, or function, of the DNA. Epigenetic mechanisms play key roles in the establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. It can cause both gene activation and inactivation.

Epigenetic modifications include:

  • DNA methylation- It is the covalent addition and subtraction of a methyl group to DNA. Methylation is typically done in cytosine preceding a guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. CpG islands are mainly present in the promoter region.
  • Histone modifications such as acetylation, deacetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, etc. Acetylation of histone activates transcription, while deacetylation represses transcription.
  • miRNA- micro RNA or miRNA are approximately 22 nucleotides long. They do not code. They bind to mRNA and inhibit its translation.

Clinical significance of epigenetic mechanisms:

  • Epigenetic modifications, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, are reversible, which makes them amenable for application in therapeutic intervention.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and DNA methylation inhibitors are being tested in the treatment of cancer. These agents inhibit transcriptional silencing and thus reverse the chromatin condensation in cancer cells.

Other Options:

Option A: Genomics refers to the comprehensive study of an organism's entire genome. Unlike epigenetics, which deals with heritable changes in gene expression without DNA sequence alterations, genomics focuses on the DNA sequence and its variations across populations.

Option B: Genetics forms the foundation for understanding inheritance patterns, genetic disorders, and trait transmission. While epigenetics deals with modifications that affect gene expression without changing the DNA sequence (such as DNA methylation and histone modifications), genetics concentrates on the DNA sequence itself and how mutations or variations in these sequences affect organisms.

Option D: The Human Genome Project (HGP) was an international research effort completed in 2003 that successfully mapped and sequenced the entire human genome, identifying approximately 20,500-25,000 genes.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe pain in her buttocks. The muscle marked in the image below is suspected to be inflamed. Which of the following nerves is likely to be involved due to its inflammation?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and the clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome. This occurs due to the entrapment of the sciatic nerve.

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle.

Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs)?

choices.text: They prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils
Nuclear chromatin in the NETs may act as source of nuclear antigens in SLE
In sepsis, platelet activation may lead to formation of NETs in the circulation
Pathogenic substances undergo phagocytosis by active nucleated neutrophils

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) is, "Pathogenic substances undergo phagocytosis by active nucleated neutrophils." In the process of neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation, the nuclei of neutrophils are lost, leading to their death. Hence, option D is a false statement.

NETs are networks of extracellular fibres that consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin. They trap microbes at sites of infection, preventing their further spread(Option A). They also contain a high concentration of antimicrobial proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, and histones that have a high affinity for DNA.

Neutrophils produce them in response to the following triggers:

  • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi.
  • Inflammatory mediators -
    • Chemokines.
    • Cytokines (mainly interferons).
    • Complement proteins
    • Reactive oxygen species

NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is involved in NET formation(Option C).

The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus(Option B). This triggers autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Cysteine is not seen in the urine of this patient.

The image shows hexagonal, translucent and white crystals suggestive of cystinuria. In cystinuria, cystine (not cysteine) is excreted in the urine. 

Cystinuria is an autosomal-recessive disease due to a defect in renal PCT & intestinal amino acid transporter that is essential for the reabsorptive transport of Cystine and the dibasic amino acids Ornithine, Lysine, and Arginine (COLA). The most specific test is the cyanide–nitroprusside test.

Cystine is urine insoluble, while the rest of the amino acids are urine soluble; thus, only cystine causes renal calculi (6-8% of total prevalence in childhood). Apart from cystine stones in the urinary tract, cystinuria is a benign condition not associated with any gastrointestinal or nutritional deficiency because of compensation by alternative transporters. Homocystinuria, ornithinemia, and hyperammonemia are not found in cystinuria. 

Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depending upon a variety of factors including:

  • The degree of concentration of constituent molecules
  • The urine pH
  • The presence of inhibitors of crystallisation

Management is ample hydration, urine alkalinization, and cystine-binding thiol drugs to increase the solubility of cystine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
questions.solution:
Cholera is not a water-washed disease. It is a water-borne disease.

Water-washed diseases are those which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances where there is inadequate water supply. Some examples of water-washed diseases include shigellosis(Option D), conjunctivitis, trachoma(Option B), scabies(Option A), typhus, polio, etc.

Water-related diseases are classified as:

Category Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal feces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses

e.g.: Cholera, typhoid, amebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrheal diseases
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene

e.g.: Scabies; trachoma; flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of water-borne diseases (which are also water-washed)
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water

e.g.: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis, and some other helminths.
Water-related vector-borne diseases 

Caused by vectors that breed in water

e.g.: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever

questions.text: Which of the following hormones have an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase?
questions.solution:
Leptin and insulin inhibit hormone-sensitive lipase, whereas the other hormones given in the options stimulate it. 

Leptin is a hormone produced by adipose tissue in proportion to the amount of body fat. It acts as a long-term regulator of energy balance. It functions by signalling the brain, specifically the hypothalamus, to regulate appetite and energy expenditure. It suppresses appetite and increases energy expenditure to maintain body weight within a certain range.

In addition to its central effects, leptin also has peripheral effects on adipose tissue. Leptin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) activity, which reduces the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids in adipocytes. This inhibition of HSL leads to reduced release of free fatty acids into the bloodstream, contributing to the overall regulation of energy storage and utilization.

Other options:

Option A: Glucagon is produced by the pancreas, glucagon stimulates hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to break down triglycerides into free fatty acids, which can be released into the bloodstream for energy production.

Option B: Epinephrine is produced by the adrenal glands, and epinephrine is released during the body's stress response. It activates HSL, promoting the breakdown of stored fat to provide energy in fight-or-flight situations.

Option C: ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) is produced by the pituitary gland, ACTH indirectly stimulates HSL activity. ACTH signals the adrenal glands to release cortisol, which can lead to the mobilization of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

questions.text: A concerned mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day-old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below.  Microscopic examination of this lesion revealed neutrophils. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over the arms of a newborn, with the presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is suggestive of transient pustular melanosis.

Transient pustular melanosis is a benign condition seen more commonly among African-American neonates than Caucasian neonates. They present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles. The pustular phase lasts for 2-3 days and no therapy is required. However, the subsequent hyperpigmented macules may last for up to 3 months.

Samples from the lesion can be cultured and smears can be prepared. They contain neutrophils and will not contain bacteria or aggregates of eosinophils. This distinguishes these lesions from those of pyoderma and erythema toxicum respectively. More dangerous lesions like the vesicular eruptions of herpes simplex and staphylococcal skin infections need to be ruled out by appropriate testing. 

Other options:

Option B - Mongolian spots are slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

Option C - Erythema toxicum is another transient condition characterized by small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.

Option D - Cutis marmorata is a transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of the skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

questions.text: Fracture through the line shown in the image is called as?
questions.solution:
The fracture shown in the given image is a hinge fracture of the base of the skull. This is also called as a motorcyclist's fracture.

It is a basal linear fracture that passes across the floor of the middle cranial fossa, often following the petrous temporal or greater wing of the sphenoid bone into the pituitary fossa. This frequently continues symmetrically across the other middle fossa separating the base of the skull into two halves, usually being caused by a heavy blow on the side of the head.

Other options:

Option A: A ring fracture is a fracture in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum. If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis, or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This force may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.

The image given below shows the fracture line of a ring fracture.

Option C: Battle's fracture is an outdated term for a fracture of the base of the skull, typically associated with a head injury. It is often identified by Battle's sign, a bruise behind the ear indicating possible basilar skull fracture.

Option D: Plumber's fracture refers to a stress fracture of the ribs, often caused by repetitive activities involving twisting or lifting. It is commonly seen in occupations requiring strenuous upper body movements, such as plumbing.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: What is the Declaration of Oslo related to?
questions.solution:
In 1970, the World Medical Association adopted a resolution on therapeutic abortion known as the Declaration of Oslo.

Other options:

Option A: Declaration of Tokyo: related to human torture and other degradation

Option C: Declaration of Helsinki: concerned with human experimentation.

Options D: Declaration of Malta: related to hunger strikes.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is secreted by the cell marked 'X' in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the C-cells or the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland and they secrete calcitonin.

The C-cells (clear cells or parafollicular cells) have a pale staining cytoplasm, they are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They are usually found in the middle third of each lateral lobe of the thyroid and scattered in between the thyroid follicles. They are members of the APUD system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells. They secrete calcitonin which lowers blood calcium.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, found mostly among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which is low in niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin can be synthesized in the body from tryptophan. Two compounds- nicotinic acid, and nicotinamide have the biological activity of niacin. The nicotinamide ring of the coenzymes NAD ( nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and NADP (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate) participate in oxidation/reduction reactions.

The initial symptoms of pellagra include loss of appetite, generalized weakness, irritability, abdominal pain, and vomiting. This is followed by bright red glossitis and a characteristic pigmented, scaly skin rash in sun-exposed areas. This rash is known as Casal’s necklace when it forms a ring around the neck. 

The 4Ds of pellagra:

Diarrhea
Dermatitis
Dementia, leading to
Death


It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

questions.text: Net reproduction rate is defined as the number of _______

choices.text: Children that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
Girls  that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
Female children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
Male children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate

questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as no. of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming a fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate.

Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR) is defined as the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15-44 or 49 years), assuming no mortality.

Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is defined as the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group.  The target is to achieve a TFR of 2.1.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins can be used for the treatment and prevention of lathyrism:
questions.solution:
Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus or its variants such as sweet pea(Lathyrus odoratus). It is mostly consumed by agricultural labourers of poor economic status because it is relatively cheap. It can present as skeletal, vascular, or neural manifestations.

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stag
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

The patient is initially able to walk with short jerky steps without any aids, but the progressive spastic paralysis causes a crossed gait, and the patient has to use sticks to maintain his balance. Eventually, the knee joints are unable to support the weight of the body and the patient cannot stand erect at all. Long-term consumption of khesari dal leads to neurolathyrism. It is characterized by gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs.

The interventions that can be used to prevent lathyrism include:

  • Vitamin C prophylaxis.
  • Limiting the proportion of the dal to less than a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed in a day.
  • Removal of the toxin by parboiling and steeping method.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a one-day history of bleeding gums, subconjunctival bleeding, and a purpuric rash. Labs showed Hb 6.4 g/dL, WBC 26,500/mm3, platelets 35,000/mm3 and coagulopathy. Peripheral smear reveals AML. Which genetic abnormality is most likely?
questions.solution:
The genetic abnormality most likely to be detected is t(15;17). It suggests acute promyelocytic variant (AML-M3) of acute myelocytic leukaemia.

This patient's low platelet count (35,000/mm³), low fibrinogen (10 mg/dL) and clinical bleeding manifestations (bleeding gums, subconjunctival bleeding, purpuric rash) point towards disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). This is most frequently seen in patients with the promyelocytic variant of acute myelocytic leukaemia. 

The combination of DIC with acute leukaemia is highly specific for AML-M3, making t(15;17) the most likely genetic abnormality. This translocation creates the PML-RARA fusion gene by joining the PML gene on chromosome 15 with the retinoic acid receptor α (RARA) gene on chromosome 17.

AML-M3 is treated differently from other AMLs, specifically with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) therapy.

Other options:

Option A: inv(16) is associated with AML-M4Eo, a distinct subtype of acute myelomonocytic leukaemia with abnormal eosinophils. This patient shows no evidence of eosinophilia.

Option B: inv(3) occurs in megakaryoblastic leukaemia (AML-M7), which typically presents with normal or elevated platelets - contrasting with this patient's severe thrombocytopenia.

Option C: t(8;21) is characteristic of AML-M2 (with maturation) and doesn't typically present with severe coagulopathy like this case.

questions.text: A hyperglycemic patient requires insulin therapy. The doctor recommends ordering an electrolyte panel before initiating insulin. Which electrolyte imbalance is most likely to occur with rapid insulin administration?
questions.solution:
Rapid insulin infusion results in hypokalemia. 

Rapid insulin infusion can lead to hypokalemia because insulin promotes the uptake of potassium ions (K⁺) into cells. When insulin is administered quickly, it stimulates the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which moves potassium from the bloodstream into cells, lowering the concentration of potassium in the extracellular fluid. This shift can result in a decrease in serum potassium levels, potentially causing hypokalemia, a condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood. Monitoring potassium levels during insulin infusion is important to prevent complications.

Rapid insulin infusion refers to the quick administration of insulin, typically through an intravenous (IV) route, to manage blood sugar levels in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) or hyperglycemic emergencies. Insulin helps lower blood glucose by facilitating glucose uptake into cells. Insulin-glucose infusions are used to treat hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of orlistat?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of orlistat is steatorrhea. 

Orlistat is an anti-obesity drug that acts by forming a covalent bond with the lipases in the gastrointestinal tract and thus decreasing fat absorption. When a usual dose of 120 mg TID is taken it blocks the digestion and absorption of dietary fat by around 30%. After discontinuation of the drug fecal content returns to normal within 48-72 hours. They can also inhibit the absorption of many fat-soluble vitamins like Vit A, D, E, and K

Side effects of orlistat:

  • Steatorrhea: most common, due to the impaired absorption of dietary fat.
  • Gastro-intestinal side effects: flatus, increased defecation
  • Renal injury: the unabsorbed fat binds with calcium, forming renal stones that can lead to oxalate nephropathy.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by a tetrad of:

  2. Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  3. Aorta overriding VSD
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy

Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Because of this, the pulmonary and systemic circulations remain separate. The cardiac silhouette usually has an egg-on-side appearance due to cardiomegaly and a narrow mediastinum. Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. In some cases, there can be massive cardiomegaly resulting in a box-shaped heart. 

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium.   • Light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes and dome pattern on silver staining(black).
