questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structures are stabilised by disulphide bonds
Secondary and tertiary structures depend upon amino acid sequence

questions.solution:
The tertiary structure is three-dimensional is the right answer among the given options. 
 

Proteins are structurally organised into four levels, as follows:

  • Primary: The linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain.
  • Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of polypeptides. Eg: alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bend.
  • Tertiary: Secondary structures arranged into larger functional units called domains.
  • Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides arranged spatially.
     
Other options:

Option B: Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures without the hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure.

Option C: Hydrogen bond and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the stabilization of secondary structure(helix). Disulfide bonds stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins.

Option D: Primary structure depends upon the amino acid sequence.

questions.text: The given ROC(Reciever Operating Characteristic)graph shows three tests A, B, and D. Arrange the tests in the sequence of worst to best.
questions.solution:
Test D is the worst test among the given three tests, Test B is better than Test D and Test A is the best as it has the highest sensitivity and the lowest false positive rate (100-specificity).

The curve shown is a Receiver operating characteristic curve(ROC). It can compare tests based on sensitivity and specificity.

A receiver operating characteristic curve(ROC) is obtained by plotting a test's true positive rate (sensitivity) against its false-positive rate ( 100- specificity) for different diagnostic cut-off points. 

The shape of the curve reflects the quality of the test. The better the test, the more it moves to the upper left (more the area under the curve). For a good test, sensitivity comes close to 100% on the y-axis, and the false positive rate comes close to 0% on the x-axis. 

Among the three tests, Test A has its curve closest to the Top left point(Ideal point) on the graph. It will have the highest AUC(Area under the curve).

Test B is second best as it is a little farther from the ideal point and has a lesser AUC.

Test D is the worst as it never goes towards the ideal point as it is a straight line. In the case of test D, as the Sensitivity of the test increases, the false positive rate also increases linearly. It will have an AUC of 0.5. Such a test is considered worthless.

The higher the AUC(AREA under the curve) of the ROC curve, the better the test. An Ideal test will have an AUC of 1.

As a rule of thumb, an AUC of 0.5 to 0.6 is almost useless, 0.6 to 0.7 is poor, 0.7 to 0.8 is fair, and 0.8 to 0.9 is very good.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters w, x, y, and z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, using primers W and Y will yield the desired product A.

Promoters or DNA regulatory elements usually precede the desired exon to be transcribed. It helps redirect transcription of only desired exons of a gene to yield a product. Alternative splicing utilizes different promoters to code slightly different products from the same gene. 

In this question, the desired product A has segments 1,3,4,5 whilst the other product B has 1,2,4,5. The difference between both is the presence of seg 3 in product A and the presence of seg 2 in product B. 

To ensure segment 2 is not transcribed, the X promoter must be excluded from the solution. Similarly, using only promoters W and Z will fail to transcribe segment 3, ruling out that combination as well. Therefore, the correct choice is promoters W and Y.

Seg 1- Needs to be transcribed and so W is essential
Seg 2- Does not need to be transcribed.
Seg 3- Needs to be transcribed and so Y is essential
Seg 4- Needs to be transcribed but Z is not essential as Y continues the transcription in the direction shown by the arrow. 

An example of the same gene yielding different products is the apolipoprotein B48 and B100. Both are produced from the same gene, the former is spliced earlier yielding B48 whilst complete transcriptions yield B100.

questions.text: What is the Nissl-free zone from where an axon arises from a neuron called?
questions.solution:
The Nissl-free zone of a neuron from where an axon arises is called an axon hillock.

Nissl bodies or granules are aggregates of polyribosomes and rough endoplasmic reticulum. They are present in the cell body of a neuron and in large dendrites. Under light microscopy, they appear as basophilic granules. The affinity towards the basic dyes is due to the presence of a large amount of RNA which is acidic in nature. 

The image below shows a photomicrograph of bluish-coloured Nissl bodies (indicated by arrows) in the cytoplasm of motor neurons.

Option A: The initial segment refers to the proximal part of the axon, that lies just beyond the axon-hillock. Thus, an axon-hillock is part of the cell body while the initial segment is part of an axon.

Option B: Mesaxon refers to the area where the plasma membrane of the Schwann cell fuses with itself around the axon. During the formation of the myelin sheath, the axon invaginates the Schwann cell. The plasma membrane of the Schwann cell fuses with itself and continues to wrap around the axon to form multiple layers of the plasma membrane called the myelin sheath. The cytoplasm and nucleus of the Schwann cell are pushed to the periphery. The thin layer of the cytoplasm of the Schwann cell surrounding the myelin sheath is called neurilemma.

Option D: Each Schwann cell myelinates only a short segment of the axon. Hence, along the length of the axon, there are several Schwann cells myelinating it. The unmyelinated portions of the axon present in between myelinated segments are known as nodes of Ranvier.

questions.text: The patient presents with pigmentation of the face as shown in the image below and gradually increasing backache and stiffness. The X-ray image of the spine is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the face, a characteristic feature of alkaptonuria, while the X-ray reveals calcification of intervertebral discs, known as ochronotic spondyloarthropathy, which is also associated with alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/ homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discolouration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue; generally occurs after the third decade of life and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

Other options:

Option A: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood. Clinical features include intellectual disability, seizures, eczema, and a distinctive musty odour in the urine.

Option C: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex, impairing the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. Clinical features include vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, and the characteristic maple syrup odour in the urine.

Option D: Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder caused by defects in the enzymes involved in the metabolism of tyrosine, leading to its accumulation in the body. Clinical features include liver dysfunction, renal tubular disease, rickets, and in severe cases, neurological deterioration.

questions.text:
A stain present on the clothes of a murder victim is being examined. Which of the following tests would help determine whether that particular stain is due to blood?
  1. Phenolphthalein test
  2. Takayama test
  3. Precipitin test
  4. Teichmann’s test
  5. Latte’s method
questions.solution:
The phenolphthalein test, Takayama test, and Teichmann’s test can be used to determine if a particular stain at a crime scene is due to blood.

Tests for determining if a stain is due to blood include the following:

Benzidine test - It is the best preliminary test for blood and is based on the peroxidase activity of blood, which changes the color of the reagent. A negative reaction rules out the presence of blood (high sensitivity). False positive reactions can occur with substances like pus, saliva, milk, rust, or bacteria.

Phenolphthalein or Kastle-Meyer test - This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple color indicates a positive test. This test is more specific for blood than the benzidine test.

Haemin crystal test or Teichmann’s test - It is done by adding glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride to a stain. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear.

Haemochromogen crystal test or Takayama test - The Takayama reagent (sodium hydroxide, pyridine, and glucose) is added to a suspected stain. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes.

Spectroscopic test - It is the most definitive test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains. It is based on the property of blood pigments to absorb rays from the spectrum, producing characteristic dark absorption bands. 

Other options:

Statement 3: The precipitin test does not determine if the stain is due to blood. Rather, it can detect whether a particular stain is of human origin or from a lower animal. The origin of skin, flesh, bone, blood, or even secretions, such as saliva, milk, and semen, is determined by this test.

Statement 5: Latte’s crust method is used on a known blood stain to determine common blood groups such as ABO, MNS, and Rh systems.

questions.text: Which nucleus in the thalamus controls pain and temperature sensations?
questions.solution:
Pain and temperature in the thalamus are controlled by the ventral posterior lateral nucleus.

 The ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus is responsible for processing sensory information related to pain and temperature from the body. Pain and temperature are carried by the anterolateral spinothalamic tract. Fibres from the anterolateral spinothalamic tract and dorsal column synapse in the ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus.

Option C: The anterior nucleus functions as a relay station for the hippocampal impulses. It receives afferents from the mammillothalamic tract. It sends efferents to the cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency, 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have:

choices.text: High plasma phosphate, High Ca2+ levels and tetanus.
Low plasma Ca2+ level, tetany, and Trousseau sign.
Low plasma phosphate and high Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone deficiency leads to low Ca+2 level, tetany and Trousseau sign.

(Please differentiate with tetanus which is caused by infection with the bacteria Clostridium tetani)

Actions of PTH include

  • PTH stimulates bone resorption, causing the release of calcium into the extracel­lular fluid;
  • PTH increases reabsorption of calcium and decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to reduced excretion of calcium and increased excretion of phosphate; and
  • PTH is necessary for the conversion of 25­-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol, which, in turn, increases calcium absorption by the intestines. 

So, a deficiency of PTH would lead to low Ca+2 levels and high Phosphate levels. 

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia - mild circumoral or digital numbness and paresthesia, carpopedal spasm, or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias. Chvostek and Trousseaus sign may be elicited. ECG changes may show QT prolongation or QRS changes.

The signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb.

Management - Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with IV and oral calcium and vitamin D replacement. 10 ml IV calcium gluconate 10% is given slowly. Supplemental Magnesium may also be required due to the synergestic actions of calcium and magnesium.

questions.text: A 20-day-old infant is struggling to breathe and is unable to feed properly. The mother lacks the financial means to visit the nearest hospital. Which national program offers assistance to help her take the child to a healthcare facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram has provisions of free transport from home to the health institutions, between facilities in case of referral and back home from the health institution. These provisions are for:

  • Pregnant women
  • Sick infants 

It includes:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood.

 Other options: 

Option A: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a safe motherhood intervention under the National Health Mission. It is being implemented to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

Option B: The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care service. With this, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in identified public health facilities (PHCs/ CHCs, DHs/ urban health facilities etc). This happens on the 9th of every month. A package of investigations (including one ultrasound during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy) and medicines such as IFA supplements, calcium supplements etc would be provided to all pregnant women attending the PMSMA clinics.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of hypopigmented patches over his chest since 6 months. Mild itching is present. The skin scraping was taken and KOH mount was prepared. On microscopy, the appearance as shown below is observed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance are suggestive of Pityriasis Versicolor.

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and a large number of variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as Spaghetti & meatballs or Bananas & grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image showing sharply demarcated multiple hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches with fine scales is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Pityriasis alba is a common, benign skin condition seen in children, characterized by hypopigmented, scaly patches on the face, arms, or neck. It is often associated with atopic dermatitis and tends to worsen with sun exposure.

Option B: Candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, commonly affecting the skin, mouth (thrush), and genital areas. It presents with itching, redness, and white plaques, and can become invasive in immunocompromised patients.

Option C: Tinea corporis is a superficial fungal infection of the skin, presenting as red, scaly, annular (ring-shaped) lesions with central clearing. It spreads through direct contact with infected individuals, animals, or contaminated surfaces.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change:
questions.solution:
The image shows suggillation.

Livor mortis/postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ suggillation refers to bluish-purple or purplish-red discolouration (due to deoxyhaemoglobin) of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body as a result of capillary-venous distention.

The timeline for the development of postmortem staining:

  • Mottled patches: 1-3 hours following the death.
  • Uniform area of staining: 3-6 hours following the death.
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis: 6-12 hours following the death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and intracranial lesions.  
    It persists until putrefaction sets in.

Medicolegal importance: Postmortem staining and its fixation can be helpful in ascertaining the time since death. It can also be used to estimate the body's position at the time of death and if the body has been relocated since. 

Other options:

Option A: Tattooing is the process of inserting ink into the dermal layer of the skin to create permanent designs. It involves using a needle to puncture the skin and deposit ink, resulting in a permanent mark or image on the body.

Option C: Putrefaction is the process of decomposition of organic matter, typically resulting from bacterial activity. It leads to the breakdown of tissues, producing foul odours and the release of gases.

Option D: Decomposition is the natural breakdown of organic matter into simpler substances, often facilitated by microorganisms. It involves stages such as autolysis, putrefaction, and mineralization, contributing to nutrient recycling in ecosystems.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the OPD with high fever, chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis. The patient also complains of watery diarrhea. The direct fluorescent antibody stain image of his pleural fluid is given below. Identify the most likely etiologic organism:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) stain image suggest the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila.

Legionella pneumophila is a fastidious, aerobic gram-negative coccobacillus. It can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements.

Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc. Human-to-human transmission does not occur. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhoea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. Hyponatremia is a feature typical to this infection leading to confusion. It is usually severe in immunocompromised patients.

Diagnosis is by the identification of legionella antigens in urine by latex agglutination or Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA). Direct fluorescent antibody test and culture on BCYE media can be used. Treatment is by newer macrolides, ciprofloxacin or tetracycline. Aminoglycoside and beta-lactam antibiotics are ineffective.

Other options:

Option A: Chlamydia pneumoniae is diagnosed through PCR (polymerase chain reaction) or serology to detect bacterial DNA or antibodies. Culture is rarely used due to the intracellular nature of the organism.

Option C: Haemophilus influenzae is diagnosed by culturing respiratory secretions, blood, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) on chocolate agar. PCR and latex agglutination tests can also detect bacterial DNA or antigens for rapid diagnosis.

Option D: Klebsiella pneumoniae is diagnosed by culturing sputum, blood, or urine on MacConkey agar, where it forms mucoid colonies. PCR and Gram staining help confirm the presence of this Gram-negative, encapsulated rod.

questions.text: A 6-year-old mentally retarded girl presented with a protuberant abdomen, short stature, coarse facial features, and cloudy corneas. Skeletal malformations include dysostosis multiplex and bullet-shaped middle phalanx. What is the enzyme deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to the diagnosis of Hurler's disease (MPS 1 H). This disease results from a deficiency of the enzyme α-L-iduronidase, which degrades glycosaminoglycans.

Hurler’s disease was previously known as gargoylism (coarse facial features), follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. The gene encoding α-L-iduronidase is present on chromosome 4. Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate are accumulated. Clinical features include coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, inguinal hernia, hepatosplenomegaly, joint stiffness, short stature, copious nasal discharge, skeletal dysplasia, hydrocephalus, and valvular heart disease. Reilly body inclusions are present in leucocytes.

Treatment: Enzyme replacement therapy is available in the form of aldurazyme.

Other options:

Option A: Hunter's disease, also known as Hunter syndrome or MPS II (Mucopolysaccharidosis type II), follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase. This leads to the buildup of complex sugars in the body, affecting organs and tissues, and primarily occurs in male children.

Option B: Morquio Syndrome B, a form of Mucopolysaccharidosis IVB (MPS IVB), is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme beta-galactosidase. It leads to the abnormal accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, affecting bone development, growth, and overall skeletal structure.

Option D: Sly syndrome, or Mucopolysaccharidosis VII (MPS VII), is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme beta-glucuronidase. This leads to the buildup of glycosaminoglycans, resulting in skeletal abnormalities, organ damage, and developmental delays.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

The Chi-square test is a non-parametric test of significance employed for two proportions using qualitative variables. It has the advantage of being of use when more than two groups are to be compared. It also offers information on the significance of any observed differences.

Tests of significance are used to check for significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as the mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: What is the respiratory quotient of lipid?
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient of lipids is 0.7.

The respiratory quotient refers to the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization. It estimates the relative utilization of different foods by the body.

Lipids require more oxygen for oxidation relative to the amount of carbon dioxide they produce because they are highly reduced molecules (contain more hydrogen and less oxygen compared to carbohydrates).

For example, during the complete oxidation of a fatty acid like palmitic acid:

C16H32O2+23O2→16CO2+16H2O

Here, the RQ is calculated as:

RQ= CO2 produced / O2 consumed=16 / 23 ≈ 0.7

questions.text: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.solution:
When a large number of tests are done in series, net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is increased.

Screening tests are done in series when the result of the first test determines whether to run the second test or not. e.g., HIV screening is done using consecutive ELISA.

Screening tests are done in parallel when the second test is independently performed regardless of what the first test result is. Both the tests are done at the same time. E.g., In LFT, multiple tests are done together like SGOT, SGPT, total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with an increased nighttime itching and lesions that are more during the winter months?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions that increase during the winter months and that cause more itching during the nighttime are seen with scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritis, excoriating papules, and burrows. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.

The following techniques can be used to diagnose scabies:

  • Skin scraping and microscopy - The material is scraped off with a blunt scalpel and is placed in mineral oil on a microscope slide. The presence of mites, eggs, fragments of eggshells, or scybala (hardened masses of faeces) confirms the diagnosis.
  • Dermoscopy - Useful for detecting burrows and visualizing their contents.
    • 10x magnification - mini triangle sign, maturing eggs that show minute heads of maturing mites within the egg.
    • 40x magnification - The mite in its burrow resembles a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’.
  • Adhesive-tape test - After firmly applying the adhesive side of the tape onto an appropriate skin lesion of patient, the tape is pulled off and transferred directly onto a slide for microscopy to visualize the mites.
  • Skin biopsy.

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.
  • Ivermectin and benzyl benzoate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

The image below shows a photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. At the upper right, the scabies mite can be seen at the end of the burrow.

The Sarcoptes scabies mite is shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with tinea infection present with circular plaques with a sharp margin and raised edges that are itchy. 

The image below shows a lesion in tinea corporis.

Option C: Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. Given below is an image of plaque psoriasis.

Option D: Photodermatosis refers to a group of skin conditions caused or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight or UV radiation. It can result in rashes, itching, or other skin reactions, often requiring sun protection or medical treatment.

questions.text: Bimodality in person distribution refers to_______.

choices.text: Description of two etiological hypotheses of a disease in one person
Evaluation of two different environmental factors of a person in disease causation
Two separate peaks instead of one in the age incidence curve of a disease
Highest point of one curve in age incidence curve of a disease

questions.solution:
Bimodality refers to the occurrence of two separate peaks, instead of one, in the age incidence curve of a disease.

Bimodal distribution refers to the occurrence of two separate peaks. It usually indicates that the study material was not homogenous, and two causative factors might be in effect. The absence of bimodality doesn't indicate that the study is homogenous.

Hodgkin's lymphoma, leukaemia and female breast cancer show a bimodal curve with double peaks.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria that causes the phenomenon shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given picture shows swarming, which is exhibited by Proteus. Proteus species move very actively through peritrichous flagella, resulting in “swarming” on solid media.

Proteus mirabilis is a gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile bacilli, which is an opportunistic urinary and nosocomial pathogen and often causes urinary tract infections in hospitalised patients following instrumentation. Proteus exhibits swarming on solid culture media wherein the colonies spread in a wave pattern, forming concentric circles.

Proteus produces urease, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide, producing a characteristic putrid or fishy odour in culture. On MacConkey agar, it produces non-lactose fermenting pale colonies, as shown below. Lactose fermenters (CEEK)- Citrobacter, Escherichia, Enterobacter, Klebsiella (Shigella sonnei is a late lactose fermenter.

The characteristic feature of proteus is the presence of the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase, converting phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA reaction). Protease also shows positivity for methyl red, but the Voges- Proskauer reaction is negative.

Other options:

Option A: Klebsiella is cultured on MacConkey or blood agar, forming large, mucoid colonies. MacConkey agar differentiates Klebsiella by lactose fermentation, producing pink colonies as shown in the image given below.

Option B: Streptococcus is cultured on blood agar, typically showing hemolysis (alpha, beta, or gamma). Todd-Hewitt broth is also used for enrichment, especially for Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B strep). Streptococcus pneumoniae produces draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies when cultured on blood agar as given in the image below.

Option C: Staphylococcus is cultured on mannitol salt agar (MSA), which selects for staphylococci and differentiates S. aureus by mannitol fermentation (yellow colonies). It also grows well on blood agar, showing hemolysis patterns. The below image shows the characteristic “Oil paint appearance” with golden yellow colour pigment formed by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral wheeze. The image of a characteristic finding in the sputum is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological image showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma.
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease.
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma.

Eosinophils are key inflammatory cells found in almost all subtypes of asthma.

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals: Made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10.
  • Curschmann spirals: Spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.
  • Creola bodies: Individual epithelial cell clusters shed in the sputum.
  • Numerous eosinophils.

The image of the sputum examination finding showing Charcot leaden crystal is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs and spreading through airborne droplets. Clinical features include chronic cough, hemoptysis, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Option C: Chronic bronchitis is a form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) characterized by persistent cough with mucus production for at least 3 months in 2 consecutive years. Common symptoms include wheezing, breathlessness, and frequent respiratory infections.

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 90 beats/min and irregular respiration. The baby coughed on inserting a nasal catheter and was moving all his limbs actively. The body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score in this newborn is 7.

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 that indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

The individual scores for all parameters given in the given clinical scenario are:

  • Appearance: Body is pink with blue extremities = 1
  • Pulse: 90 beats/min = 1
  • Grimace: Coughs on nasal catheter insertion = 2
  • Active motion: Moves all the limbs actively = 2
  • Respiratory effort - Irregular respiration = 1

Thus the total score in this baby is 7. 

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep. He is feeling comfortable only after doing so. He is also experiencing burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs. What is the ideal drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of the student complaining of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep and feeling comfortable only after doing so, along with having burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs indicative of a diagnosis of restless leg syndrome and the ideal  drug of choice for this condition is gabapentin.

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep or an uncomfortable sensation of creeping-crawling feeling. It is worse at night and moving legs or walking reduces discomfort. 

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

Other options:

  • Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • Rilmenidine is an imidazoline receptor agonist that is used for the management of hypertension.
  • Rimonabant is an inverse agonist of the CB1 (cannabinoid receptor) that was used as an anti-obesity medication.

questions.text: A man was found to be lying dead on the ground. His friend saw a snake passing in the area and took a picture of it and showed it to the doctor (image below). What is the most probable cause of death of this man?
questions.solution:
The snake in the given image with single white bands on the body is a Common krait which is neurotoxic and the most probable cause of death in this patient is respiratory failure. 

Bites of Elapidae (Cobras, Kraits, Mambas, Coral Snakes) present with a local bite reaction which is generally mild with minimal swelling, blistering or superficial necrosis. However their neurotoxic effects are prominent and early symptoms usually include vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, the heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and ‘gooseflesh’. 

Ptosis is the earliest neuroparalytic manifestation followed
by ophthalmoplegia. 
This is followed by paralysis of the facial muscles, palate, jaws, tongue, vocal cords, neck muscles. Muscles of deglutition become progressively flaccidly paralyzed. 
A respiratory arrest may occur due to obstruction of the upper airway by the paralyzed tongue or inhaled vomitus, or due to paralysis of intercostal muscles and diaphragm.

Other options:

Options A and C: Viper snake bite (hemotoxic) can lead to shock, haemorrhage, and consumptive coagulopathy.

Option D: Sea snake bites (myotoxic) often result in death due to cardiac arrest caused by hyperkalemia from renal failure or due to respiratory failure.

questions.text: A patient presented with a swelling in his right foot with multiple discharging sinuses that contained brown granules. The lesion did not respond to antibiotic medications. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The history of multiple discharging sinuses that contained brown granules and the non-responsiveness to the antibiotics are suggestive of Eumycetoma. The causative agent of this is Madurella mycetomatis.

Madurella mycetomatis is a fungus commonly associated with mycetoma, a chronic granulomatous infection affecting the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and bones. It is primarily found in tropical and subtropical regions and typically enters the body through trauma to the skin.

Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and bone which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. Mycetoma occurs worldwide. It can be caused by fungi in which case it is called eumycetoma. Madurella mycetomatis is the most common fungal causative agent. Species of Actinomadura and Nocardia belonging to actinomyces can also cause mycetoma in which case it is referred to as actinomycetoma. Botyromycosis is another form of mycetoma caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources, usually on thorns or splinters, and results in tumefactions, deformities, and draining sinuses discharging fungal colonies called grains or granules. Subcutaneous tissues of the feet, lower extremities, hands, and exposed areas are most often involved. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the colour of which depends on the organism responsible.

The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain since 4 days. Stool microscopy was done and is shown below. The eggs present in the stool is found to float in a saturated solution of salt. Which of the following can be used for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the stool microscopy showing a spherical or ovoid, non-bile stained egg with a thin colourless outer membrane and a thin embryophore covering the hexacanth embryo, is diagnostic of Hymenolepis nana infection. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with H. nana. 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm. Humans are the definitive host. It has no intermediate host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The egg attaches to the intestine and develops into the larva and adult worm. The adult worm resides in the small intestine.  

Patients are usually asymptomatic. However, in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response. It can also cause autoinfection. Internal autoinfection occurs when the eggs are released in the intestine and hatch there. External autoinfection occurs through the ingestion of the eggs by the fecal-oral route. They hatch in the small intestine to release the hexacanth embryo, which penetrates the intestinal villus, resulting in autoinfection.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. They have a thin colorless outer membrane and thread-like polar filaments on stool microscopy. They have a hexacanth embryo. 
Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with H. nana. 

Other options:

Option A: Ivermectin is an antiparasitic drug effective against nematodes, scabies, and lice by paralyzing and killing the parasites. Its mechanism of action involves binding to glutamate-gated chloride channels, increasing chloride permeability, and leading to neuromuscular paralysis of the parasite.

Option B: Mebendazole is an antiparasitic drug used to treat intestinal helminth infections like ascariasis, hookworm, and pinworm. It works by inhibiting microtubule formation, disrupting glucose uptake and depleting the parasite’s energy stores, leading to the death of the worm.

Option D: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is used to treat filariasis and tropical eosinophilia by targeting microfilariae and adult worms. Its mechanism involves disrupting parasite membranes and altering muscle activity, making them more susceptible to immune attack.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient who is an athlete presents with pruritus of the groin. Examination of the groin reveals the following findings. He is diagnosed with a fungal infection. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing dry, erythematous, and a circumferential lesion in the groin is suggestive of tinea cruris. The most probable causative organism among the given options for tinea cruris is Trichophyton rubrum. 

Tinea cruris, or jock itch, refers to an infection that can involve the genital, pubic, perineal, and perianal skin. It is usually caused by dermatophytes like Trichyphyton rubrum or Epidermophyton floccosum. 

T. rubrum belongs to the dermatophyte group. Dermatophytes are classified as microsporum, trichophytoin, and epidermophyton. They are hyaline, filamentous fungi that enzymatically digest the keratin. Dermatophytes cause infection of the keratin-containing structures. These include the skin, hair, and nails. 

Infections caused by dermatophytes include the following: 

  • Tinea barbae - beard 'barber's itch' 
  • Tinea corporis - body 
  • Tinea imbricata - a type of tinea corporis that exists in the tropical climate
  • Tinea capitis - scalp 
  • Tinea cruris - groin 'jock itch'
  • Tinea pedis - foot 'athlete's foot'
  • Tinea manuum - hand
  • Tinea unguium - nails 

The examination will reveal erythematous, pruritic, circular, scaly patches.  

Diagnosis of dermatophyte infection is done with Wood's lamp which will reveal fluorescence. KOH preparation will reveal branching hyaline septate hyphae. Sabouraud dextrose agar is used to culture dermatophytes. 

Topical azoles like miconazole, clotrimazole, or terbinafine are used to treat dermatophyte infections. 

Other options: 

Option A - Exophiala weneckii causes tinea nigra, an infection of the stratum corneum in the areas of the palm leading to dark macules. 

Option C - Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor. This fungus causes infection of the stratum corneum leading to discolored or depigmented macules over the thorax, abdomen, and upper limbs. 

Option D - Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra, infection of the hair. It is characterized by firm, irregular nodules on the hair shaft.

questions.text: What type of prevention is it when benzathine benzylpenicillin is administered for streptococcal sore throat to prevent rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
When benzathine benzylpenicillin is given for streptococcal sore throat to prevent rheumatic fever, it is a primary mode of intervention, as the disease has not occurred yet.

However, the use of benzathine benzylpenicillin given in rheumatic fever is a secondary mode of intervention as the disease has already occurred and the complications need to be prevented.

Primary prevention is defined as any intervention that removes the possibility that any disease will occur. Examples include HPV vaccination to prevent HPV infection, which can lead to cervical cancer.

Other options: 

Option B: Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken in this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education. Examples include discouraging harmful modes of lifestyle like smoking from early childhood, as it can lead to adult health problems.

Option C: Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific interventions used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.

Option D: Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and to minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

Neisseria meningitidis is an aerobic, gram-negative, nonmotile diplococcus that is catalase and oxidase-positive. It oxidizes glucose and maltose but not lactose or sucrose. The bacteria typically spread from the nasopharynx to the meninges via the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve following an initial flu-like infection.

Meningococcemia often starts with acute fever, chills, malaise, and a petechial rash. As the disease advances, symptoms of meningitis, such as severe headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck, may develop, potentially progressing to coma within a few hours. In its fulminant form, meningococcemia presents with high fever and a hemorrhagic rash and can lead to severe complications like disseminated intravascular coagulation, circulatory collapse, and Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome, characterized by bilateral adrenal gland necrosis and subsequent adrenal failure.

Meningitis can rapidly progress to fulminant meningococcemia, evolving from acute illness to severe disease in hours. Classic meningitis symptoms include fever, headache, neck stiffness, and decreased consciousness. Nuchal rigidity, along with Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs, may indicate meningeal irritation, though their sensitivity can vary. Seizures, occurring in 15-40% of patients, may result from complications like raised intracranial pressure, leading to severe outcomes such as cerebral herniation. The rash associated with meningococcemia evolves quickly from a diffuse maculopapular appearance to the trunk, extremities, mucous membranes, and sometimes palms and soles.

Other options:

Option B: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative, opportunistic pathogen known for causing nosocomial infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients. It can lead to pneumonia, wound infections, and sepsis, and is notable for its antibiotic resistance and biofilm formation.

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive, encapsulated bacterium that commonly causes pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media. It spreads through respiratory droplets and its polysaccharide capsule is a key virulence factor, aiding in immune evasion.

Option D: Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a Gram-negative bacterium that normally resides in the gut, aiding digestion, but pathogenic strains can cause urinary tract infections, gastroenteritis, and sepsis. It spreads through contaminated food, water, or person-to-person contact.

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: The following instrument is used to measure ________
questions.solution:
The image given is that of an Assmann psychrometer which is used to measure humidity.

Psychrometers are instruments used for the measurement of air humidity. The commonly used are:

  • Assman psychrometer.
  • Dry and wet bulb hygrometer
  • Sling psychrometer

These instruments consist of two thermometers, a wet and dry one. The relative humidity is then calculated using the readings of these thermometers and psychometric charts. 

The Assman psychrometer is a portable instrument designed to give an accurate measurement of the wet and dry bulb temperature of the air. This instrument draws in air at a speed of > 5 m/sec by a clock-work fan after which readings are noted. The bulbs of the thermometer are protected from solar radiation so that the instrument can be used even in strong sunshine.

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer is the most widely used instrument for measuring air humidity. It consists of two identical thermometers - a dry-bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer, mounted side by side on a stand. 

A Sling psychrometer also known as a whirling psychrometer consists of two thermometers (wet and dry) mounted side by side, on a suitable wooden frame, and provided with a handle for rotating the instrument as shown below. The wet bulb is rotated for 15 seconds facing away from the sun to obtain an airspeed of about 5 m/sec after which readings are noted.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

questions.text: Hyperammonemia inhibits the TCA cycle, by depleting levels of which of the following substances
questions.solution:
Hyperammonemia results in the depletion of alpha-ketoglutarate.

This happens in two steps.

  • Glutamine Formation: When blood ammonia levels are elevated (hyperammonemia), the body activates a protective mechanism to reduce free ammonia levels. Glutamine synthetase catalyzes the reaction between ammonia (NH3) and glutamate to form glutamine. This consumes one molecule of glutamate for each molecule of ammonia detoxified:

    Glutamate + NH3 + ATP → Glutamine + ADP + Pi

  • α-Ketoglutarate Depletion: To maintain cellular glutamate levels that were depleted in Step 1, cells convert α-ketoglutarate to glutamate through the following reaction catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase:

α-Ketoglutarate + NH3 + NADPH → Glutamate + NADP+

Thus, hyperammonemia eventually depletes alpha-ketoglutarate and as α-ketoglutarate is a critical TCA cycle intermediate, its depletion impairs the cycle's function.

The impairment of the TCA cycle has severe consequences:

  • Reduced ATP production.
  • Compromised energy metabolism.
  • Potential cellular dysfunction, particularly in tissues with high energy demands like the brain.
  • Can contribute to the neurological symptoms seen in hyperammonemia.

questions.text: A 35 yr old man presents with headache. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated. He has coarse facial features and frontal bossing, large hands and feet, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and a large fleshy nose. His age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acromegaly and is due to excess growth hormone (GH).

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism.

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumour. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analogue), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists, or radiation.

Other options:

Option B: Growth Hormone (GH) deficiency can lead to short stature and delayed growth in children, and reduced muscle mass, fatigue, and osteoporosis in adults. It may result from genetic factors, pituitary disorders, or brain injuries.

Option C: Excess somatostatin can inhibit growth hormone, insulin, and gastrin, causing symptoms like diabetes, gallstones, and digestive issues. It is often seen in somatostatinomas and rare pancreatic or duodenal tumours.

Option D: Deficiency of somatostatin can lead to excess secretion of growth hormone, insulin, and gastrin, potentially causing acromegaly, hyperinsulinemia, and peptic ulcers. This imbalance can result in uncontrolled hormone activity and digestive disturbances.

questions.text: Which among the following is a cell cycle independent anti-cancer drug?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a cell cycle independent anti-cancer drug.

Its mode of action has been linked to its ability to crosslink with the purine bases on the DNA, interfering with DNA repair mechanisms, causing DNA damage, and subsequently inducing apoptosis in cancer cells.

It is used in the treatment of testicular, bladder, ovary, and lung carcinomas. However, there are incidences of drug resistance and numerous undesirable side effects such as:

  • Severe kidney injury
  • Hearing loss especially in younger patients 
  • Decrease immunity to infections
  • Marked emesis
  • Electrolyte disturbances like hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia
  • Allergic reactions

Hence, other platinum-containing anti-cancer drugs such as carboplatin, oxaliplatin have been used.

Other options:

Option B- Vinblastin is an M phase-specific anti-cancer drug. Vinca alkaloids bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerization into microtubules → prevents mitotic spindle formation.

Option C- Cladribine is an S phase-specific anti-cancer drug. It is incorporated into DNA where it produces DNA strand breaks and depletion of NAD and ATP, leading to apoptosis. Also, it is a potent inhibitor of ribonucleotide reductase.

Option D- Topotecan is an S phase-specific anticancer drug. It inhibits topoisomerase 1 and prevents DNA unwinding and replication.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with seizures, intellectual disability, and subependymal nodules on the MRI brain. On examination, the following cutaneous lesion is seen. Name the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the image shows ash leaf macules seen in this condition.

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the presence of benign congenital tumors in multiple organs. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. Loss-of-function mutations of these tumour suppressor genes (TSC1&2) are present. It presents during childhood with intellectual disability, skin lesions, and seizures. On brain MRI, subependymal nodules can be seen.

The clinical features include seizures, intellectual disability, white ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs. Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), a shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin‐coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region. Periungual fibromas and renal angiomyolipomas

questions.text: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows ‘47, XXY’ abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome. Gynecomastia and long limbs are seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

Other clinical features seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome are: 

  • Disproportionately long arms and legs,
  • Gynecomastia
  • Eunuchoid body habitus
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80,
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities,
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma
  • Testicular dysgenesis with small penis
  • Infertility/azoospermia
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Higher risk of extragonadal germ cell tumors

Klinefelter syndrome:

  • Most common sex aneuploidy in males
  • Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY
  • Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division)

Note:

A variant of Klinefelter’s syndrome—49, XXXXY—presents with short stature

Other options:

Option B: Flat occiput:

Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is characterized by intellectual disability and distinctive physical features including a round face with flat occiput, protruding tongue, and flat nasal bridge. Characteristic facial features include oblique palpebral fissures (mongoloid slant), epicanthal folds, Brushfield's spots, and low-set dysplastic ears. Notable hand and foot abnormalities include incurved/short fifth finger with clinodactyly, simian palmar crease, and a sandal gap between the first and second toes.

Option C: Turner syndrome (45,XO) is characterized by webbing of neck and lymphedema. Short stature, short fourth metacarpal, sensorineural hearing loss, and shield chest deformity are also seen. Patients present with primary amenorrhea, infertility, and absent Barr body. The condition features distinctive cardiovascular defects, cubitus valgus, and congenital lymphedema. Reproductive abnormalities include underdeveloped streak ovaries with increased risk of gonadoblastoma if Y chromosome material is present. Additional characteristic features include webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and horseshoe kidneys.

Option D: Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) is characterized by short stature and polydactyly, along with distinctive craniofacial features including midline cleft lip, ocular hypotelorism, bulbous nose, and low-set malformed ears. The syndrome presents with significant neurological involvement (microcephaly, holoprosencephaly), ocular defects (microphthalmia), and multiple systemic manifestations including cardiac malformations, scalp defects, skeletal abnormalities (hypoplastic/absent ribs), and visceral/genital anomalies. These severe malformations typically result in profound developmental delay and limited survival.

questions.text: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given:  should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 10th standard. What is this health worker called?
questions.solution:
The requirements of being a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and having a formal education till 10th standard is for an ASHA(Accredited Social Health Activist) worker. 

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of at least up to 10th grade. . This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years (married/divorced/widow) and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population, but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices.
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breastfeeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception.
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infections/sexually transmitted infections.
  • To mobilize the community and help them in accessing health and health-related services.
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility.
  • To inform the sub-centre/primary health centre about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community.
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign.

Other options:

Option A: An Anganwadi worker is a community-based health worker in India, primarily responsible for providing maternal and child health services, nutrition, and education. They work under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program to support the well-being of children and mothers.

Option B: A nurse is a healthcare professional responsible for providing patient care, administering medications, and assisting with treatment plans. They play a crucial role in promoting health, preventing illness, and supporting recovery across various healthcare settings.

Option C: A midwife is a trained professional who specializes in assisting women during pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period. They provide prenatal care, support during labour, and postnatal care for both the mother and newborn.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy sustained a wound in the forearm while playing on the ground. The wound was bleeding for some time and stopped after the formation of a blood clot. The type of homeostasis mechanism acting in this scenario is also seen in all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the process of blood clotting which is an example of positive feedback. This is also seen in all the other conditions except pulmonary hyperventilation which is an example of negative feedback.

Pulmonary hyperventilation is a negative feedback mechanism where a stimulus (like increased CO2 in blood) leads to a response- pulmonary hyperventilation which reduces the original stimulus (blood CO2 level decreases) and brings back the system to its original state.

Positive feedback is the type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state. Negative feedback is a system where the initial stimulus triggers a response that restores the original state. 

Most mechanisms in our body follow the negative feedback mechanism which helps to maintain homeostasis. For example, an increase in gastric acids leads to a decrease in gastric secretion.

Positive feedback is seen in a few conditions where a physiological process has to propagate itself. These include:

  • Childbirth
  • Lactation
  • Blood clotting
  • LH surge
  • Action potential

Positive feedback may sometimes lead to vicious cycles, eg. shock.

questions.text:
Which among the following disorders does not follow the classic mendelian inheritance?
  1. Angelman syndrome
  2. Marfan syndrome
  3. Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  4. Prader -Willi syndrome
  5. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, Angelman syndrome (1), Kearns-Sayre syndrome (3), and Prader-Willi syndrome (4) do not follow a classic Mendelian inheritance pattern.

The non-mendelian inheritance pattern is used to describe mitochondrial inheritance, trinucleotide repeat disorders, and genetic imprinting.

Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome arise due to genetic imprinting. Here, the gene expression depends on the parental origin of the chromosome. It results due to an imbalance in the active copies of a specific gene. In Angelman syndrome, the maternal copy is affected while the paternal one is affected in Prader-Willi syndrome. Both the syndromes present with developmental delays and mental retardation. 

Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a mitochondrial disorder that results in lactic acidosis, pigmentary retinitis, and progressive external ophthalmoplegia. 

The classic forms of genetic inheritances such as autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked inheritance are referred to as Mendelian inheritance forms.

Autosomal dominant inheritance is marked by the presence of one abnormal gene on one of the autosomes/ chromosomes 1-22. Autosomal recessive inheritance requires both copies of the same to be abnormal. If genes located on the X chromosome are affected, an X-linked pattern of inheritance with males being affected more commonly is seen. 

Other Options:

Option 2: Marfan's syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Features include tall stature, arachnodactyly, lens subluxation, and aortic root dilatation. 

Option 5: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder that is characterized by the involvement of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs. Calf hypertrophy is a characteristic feature.
