questions.text: A neonatologist advises the family of a newborn weighing 1.9 kg to practice the following method. What is incorrect about the baby's positioning in this method?

choices.text: Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position.
The abdomen should be at the level of mother's epigastrium.
The legs should be extended and adducted.

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care (KMC), and the baby's legs must be flexed and abducted, not extended and adducted.

The Kangaroo positioning:

  • Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position. It keeps the airway of the baby open and allows eye-to-eye contact with the mother. 
  • The abdomen should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. The mother's breathing stimulates the baby, thus preventing apnea. 
  • The arms should be flexed.
  • The legs should be flexed and abducted in a 'Frog' position. 

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components:

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

KMC can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC can even be done on mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with a thyroid swelling. The histology of the swelling shows amyloid deposits in the thyroid stroma. Investigations reveal elevated calcitonin levels. Which of the following is most likely associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid which can occur in the setting of MEN syndrome 2A or 2B.

Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine neoplasms derived from the parafollicular cells or C cells of the thyroid. About 70% of tumours arise sporadically. The remaining 30% occurs in the setting of MEN syndrome 2A or 2B or as familial tumours. RET mutations are seen in both hereditary and sporadic tumours.

Medullary carcinomas arising in the context of MEN-2B are generally more aggressive and metastasize more frequently than those occurring in patients with sporadic tumours. These tumours present with a mass in the neck; dysphagia, hoarseness, or diarrhoea due to the secretion of VIP; or Cushing syndrome due to ACTH. Bilaterality and multicentricity are common in familial cases.

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles. Acellular amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma. These lesions secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen.

The histopathological slide of medullary carcinoma thyroid is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN 1) is an autosomal dominant disorder. The classic triad of MEN 1 involves tumors of the parathyroid glands (causing primary hyperparathyroidism), pancreatic islet cells (particularly gastrinomas and insulinomas), and pituitary gland (most commonly prolactinomas). Unlike MEN 2 syndromes, MEN 1 does not involve medullary thyroid carcinoma or pheochromocytomas.  

Option C: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by germline mutations in the TP53 tumor suppressor gene. It predisposes affected individuals to a wide range of malignancies, particularly soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, adrenocortical carcinomas, and leukemias. Unlike MEN syndromes, Li-Fraumeni syndrome does not typically involve medullary thyroid carcinoma or other endocrine neoplasias as characteristic features. 

Option D: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas with sufficient iodine intake. It's an autoimmune disorder characterized by progressive destruction of the thyroid gland mediated by antibodies and T-cell-mediated immunity. Unlike medullary thyroid carcinoma, it primarily affects the follicular cells rather than C-cells and does not produce calcitonin.

Related Pearl: Secretion of medullary thyroid tumors

Medullary thyroid tumor secrete the following:

  • Calcitonin
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Calcitonin gene–related peptide
  • Histaminadases
  • Prostaglandins E 2 and F 2 α
  • Serotonin

Calcitonin and serotonins are responsible for diarrhea in MTC.

Option B: Isoproterenol increases systolic blood pressure by increasing contractility and increases heart rate due to its β1 action. The β2-mediated vasodilation, results in a decrease in mean arterial pressure and reflex tachycardia.

questions.text:
Identify the causative organism of the following lesion.

EBV-Epstein Barr virus
questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the picture is herpes labialis caused by HSV-1.

Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes which is characterised by vesiculoulcerative lesions of the penis of the male or of the cervix, vulva, vagina, and perineum of the female.

The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers that heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is in the face, cheeks, chin, around the mouth and forehead. A cesarean section is performed in a case of active genital herpes at the time of labour in order to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

Acyclovir, at a high dose of 60 mg/kg/day, administered intravenously every eight hours, should be the first line of treatment for any infant with a confirmed or suspected neonatal HSV infection.

The image below shows herpes labialis.

Other options:

Option B: Epstein Barr virus affects adolescents and younger adults more frequently but may occur from childhood to old age. It is transmitted primarily through close contact with oropharyngeal secretions. The incubation period of EBV infectious mononucleosis is 4-6 weeks. Clinically, patients may present with, fever, malaise, nausea, anorexia, lymphadenopathy- bilateral and symmetrical, pharyngitis, tonsillar enlargement, hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

Option C: Measles is caused by the measles virus from the paramyxoviridae family. The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, URTI, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This follows the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face below the hairline and spreads to the torso and extremities.

Option D: Rubella, also known as German measles is caused by the rubella virus, an enveloped RNA virus belonging to the family Togaviridae. The period of infectivity is usually a week before and a week after the onset of the rash appears and the incubation period is around 2-3 weeks. The child presents with low-grade fever, centrifugal macular rash, and prominent lymphadenopathy (suboccipital, postauricular, and anterior cervical lymph nodes). Forchheimer spots which are tiny rose-colored lesions on the soft palate may be present.

  2. Mucosal: most common site involved is buccal mucosa. It may cause Gingivostomatitis & Pharyngitis, Recurrent herpes labialis.
  3. Ophthalmic: Follicular conjunctivitis, Herpes simplex keratitis, and acute keratoconjunctivitis also occur. 
  4. Nervous System: HSV encephalitis(Temporal lobe involvement), HSV meningitis, Mollaret’s meningitis.

questions.text: In a population of 10,000, the prevalence of a disease is 20%. The sensitivity of a screening test is 95% and specificity is 80%. The positive predictive value of the test would be _____
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the positive predictive value(PPV) of the test would be 54.3%.

PPV is defined as the probability that a person who tests positive for a disease, actually has the disease, ie, is a true positive. Therefore, if a disease is highly prevalent in an area, and someone from that area tests positive for the disease, the chances this person actually has the disease would be higher.

  • The prevalence of the disease is 20% in 10,000, i.e., 2000 people are diseased (TP + FN) and 8000 are disease-free (FP + TN).
  • The sensitivity of the test is 95%, i.e., TP/(TP + FN) = 95%.
  • Thus, the true positives (TP) = 1900.
  • The specificity of the test is 80%, i.e., TN/(FP + TN) = 80%.
  • Thus, the true negatives (TN) = 6400.

An alternate formula that can be used is PPV = (Sensitivity x Prevalence) / (Sensitivity x Prevalence)+[(1-Specificity)(1-Prevalence)].

questions.text: The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the ________.
questions.solution:
The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the secondary attack rate.

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period.

It is calculated by the formula:

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator. The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

Other options:

Option B: Case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a disease who die from it, reflecting the severity of the condition. It is calculated by dividing the number of deaths by the number of diagnosed cases and multiplying by 100.

Option C: Primary attack rate measures the proportion of people who develop a disease after exposure to an infectious agent. It reflects the spread and initial impact of the disease within a susceptible population.

Option D: Tertiary attack rate refers to the spread of disease among contacts of secondary cases, highlighting further transmission within a population. It helps assess the extent of ongoing transmission beyond initial exposure.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Incidence rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time ) x 1000

Incidence rate of spells of sickness = ( Number of spells of sickness starting in a specified period /Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time ) x 1000

Attack rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time /Total population at risk during the given time ) x 100

Secondary attack rate = ( Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of the incubation period/Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts ) x 100

Prevalence = ( Number of all cases (new+old) of a specified disease at a given point in time/ Estimated population at the same point in time ) x 100

questions.text: On autopsy of a person with suspected poisoning, a characteristic finding of softening of basal ganglia is found. Which of the following is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the autopsy of a person suspected of poisoning reveals a characteristic finding of softening of the basal ganglia. The most likely cause of this is carbon monoxide poisoning.

Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning occurs when carbon monoxide gas is inhaled, often from sources like faulty heating systems, car exhaust, or smoke. CO binds to haemoglobin in the blood, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. This leads to hypoxia and tissue damage, especially in oxygen-sensitive organs like the brain and heart.

Systemic asphyxiants such as carbon monoxide and cyanide severely reduce the body's ability to utilize oxygen. The central nervous system is the most sensitive to these effects, followed by the heart. Most commonly, this manifests as softening of the basal ganglia (mostly globus pallidus) and this is seen with both carbon monoxide and cyanide. 

Symptoms of CO poisoning include headache, dizziness, nausea, and confusion, and in severe cases, it can lead to unconsciousness, seizures, or death. Diagnosis is made through blood tests to measure carboxyhemoglobin levels. Treatment involves administering 100% oxygen to displace CO from haemoglobin and accelerate its elimination from the body.

Other options:

Option B: Ammonia poisoning occurs when ammonia gas is inhaled or absorbed, leading to respiratory distress and neurological symptoms such as confusion and agitation. It can result in severe tissue damage, especially to the lungs, and requires prompt treatment with airway management and ammonia neutralization.

Option C: Carbon dioxide poisoning occurs from excessive inhalation of CO₂, leading to respiratory acidosis, headache, dizziness, and shortness of breath. Severe exposure can cause loss of consciousness and asphyxiation, requiring immediate oxygen therapy and ventilation support.

Option D: Opioid poisoning causes respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and unconsciousness. Immediate treatment includes administering naloxone, an opioid antagonist, and providing respiratory support.

The wastes are categorised and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A colour coding system with 4 colours namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then disposed of by various methods. They are: 

  • Incineration - this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection - chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes.
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process.
  • Microwave irradiation - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely.
  • Land disposal - either municipal disposal sites or sanitary landfills are used.
  • Inertization - waste is mixed with cement and other substances before disposal to reduce toxicity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with a widespread rash. It started on the chest and spread out over his body. On examination, there are multiple purpuric macules affecting the face and torso. Nikolsky's sign is positive. There is also the involvement of his mouth and eyes. The body surface area affected is 10%. He was recently started on allopurinol for gout. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). 

SJS is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (Option B).

The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. 

Patients usually present 7-10 days after consuming the drug with malaise and fever. It then progresses to a skin rash starting on the face and chest which then spreads over the rest of the body. There are purpuric macules that can easily be desquamated. Positive Nikolsky's sign may be present (gentle lateral pressure causing sliding of the epidermis).

Eyes, oral mucosa, and genitals are frequently involved. 

SJS/TEN is classified based on severity and involvement of body surface area (BSA)

SJS/TEN overlap Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN with spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

Complications of SJS/TEN involve loss of thermoregulatory control, severe dehydration, and septicemia. Dehydration can cause acute kidney injury due to hypoperfusion. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and be monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.

The following image shows the involvement of the oral mucosa and large areas of loss of skin.

Patients usually present with oral lesions which are the predominant feature. There are flaccid blisters which rupture. The following image shows the multiple ruptured and flaccid blisters.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese lady with diabetes was managed with a thiazolidinedione group of oral hypoglycemic agents. Which of the following adverse effects is not associated with this group of drugs?
questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia as an adverse effect is not associated with thiazolidinediones group of oral hypoglycemic agents. 

The thiazolidinedione group of drugs (pioglitazone, rosiglitazone) activates PPAR-γ receptors in adipose tissue and skeletal muscles. These are insulin sensitizers and increase insulin-mediated glucose uptake in patients with type 2 diabetes. These also reduce hepatic glucose production and increase glucose uptake.

Thiazolidinediones (e.g., pioglitazone) can cause fluid retention, leading to oedema and heart failure exacerbation. Activated PPAR-γ receptors in the collecting ducts trigger increased ENaC-mediated sodium retention and upregulate vascular endothelial growth factor, creating a dual hit of plasma volume expansion and capillary leak.

They may also increase the risk of bone fractures and bladder cancer with long-term use. PPAR-γ overactivation skews bone marrow progenitor cell fate away from osteoblastogenesis and toward adipogenesis, resulting in decreased bone matrix synthesis and compromised skeletal integrity.

Sustained PPAR-γ signaling alters bladder epithelial cell homeostasis through dysregulated proliferation pathways and anti-apoptotic mechanisms, potentially creating a permissive environment for neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 20 days. The stool examination shows the following organism. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The clinical history and image showing the pear/tennis racket/heart/pyriform-shaped trophozoite form suggests giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is a common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans. Infection is by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts, or by directly by the feco-oral route.

It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals. The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection. The trophozoite is heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped with 2 equally sized nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella. It exhibits slow oscillating motility that resembles the movement of a falling leaf. 

Giardiasis is diagnosed by the identification of cysts or trophozoites in the faeces or small intestines or by nucleic acid amplification tests. Wet mount preparation of stool samples may show the presence of a small, oval cyst surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall or a trophozoite shaped like a tennis racket. It is also referred to as heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped.

Metronidazole and tinidazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

Images of the cyst and trophozoite of giardia are given below:

Other options:

Option A: Isospora belli is a protozoan parasite that causes intestinal coccidiosis, leading to watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. It primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, with diagnosis made by detecting oocysts in stool samples.

The image given below shows the uniformly acid-fast, large, oval oocysts of Isospora belli.

Option B: Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite that causes cryptosporidiosis, leading to watery diarrhoea, nausea, and abdominal cramps. It spreads through contaminated water or food and is particularly severe in immunocompromised individuals.

The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.

Option C: Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a common bacterium found in the intestines of humans and animals, most strains of which are harmless. However, some types, such as E. coli O157:H7, can cause severe foodborne illnesses.

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the following vector found in cracks and crevices of walls during daytime?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a sandfly. They transmit visceral leishmaniasis.

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anaemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

  • Amstigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to the nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. The flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Other options: 

Options A and C: Japanese encephalitis and Dengue are transmitted via the Aedes mosquito.

Option D: Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by tsetse fly.

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose-water, develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of ___________?
questions.solution:
A newborn begins refusing breast milk on the second day while tolerating glucose water and, by the fifth day, develops vomiting and severe jaundice, with laboratory findings revealing a positive Benedict's test and low blood and urine glucose levels, suggesting the diagnosis of classical galactosemia which occurs due to a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The clinical features of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency include the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver, leading to liver damage, hepatomegaly, vomiting, and convulsions. The depletion of inorganic phosphate in the liver reduces ATP synthesis, impairing gluconeogenesis and causing hypoglycemia.

Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves can result in intellectual disability, while the buildup of galactitol in the lens causes an oil-drop cataract, as shown below. 

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and the Mucic acid test are positive. Treatment is a galactose-free diet.

The flowchart representing galactose metabolism is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Aldose reductase is an enzyme in the polyol pathway that converts glucose to sorbitol using NADPH as a cofactor. It plays a role in diabetic complications, as sorbitol accumulation can lead to cataracts and nerve damage.

Option B: Galactokinase is an enzyme that catalyzes the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate in the galactose metabolism pathway. Its deficiency leads to the accumulation of galactitol, causing early-onset cataracts.

Option D: UDP-galactose-4-epimerase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of UDP-galactose to UDP-glucose in galactose metabolism. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to galactosemia, causing symptoms such as cataracts and liver damage.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presented with ascending left-sided flank pain during micturition and recurrent episodes of urinary tract infections. The urologist suspects vesicoureteric reflux. Which of the following investigations can be done to confirm this condition?

DMSA: Dimercapto succinic acid
questions.solution:
A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) can be done to confirm vesicoureteric reflux.

Vesicoureteric reflux is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder back to the ureter and kidney. The condition is usually congenital and familial. It is more commonly seen in females during evaluation for a urinary tract infection. It predisposes the child to pyelonephritis resulting in renal injury or scarring. This is known as reflux-related renal injury or reflux nephropathy.

The international reflux study (IRS) classification divides it into grades I-V based on the severity as shown below. This is based on the appearance seen in contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

Recurrent urinary tract infections are commonly seen in cases with grade III or IV vesicoureteric reflux. The condition is diagnosed by a voiding cystourethrogram. This is done by catheterization of the bladder followed by instillation of an iodinated contrast. Vesicoureteric reflux done during voiding is known as high-pressure vesicoureteric reflux. A low-dose radiation contrast VCUG provides anatomic information such as a duplex collecting system, ectopic ureter, and bladder diverticulum.

The image below shows dilated ureters seen in a case of vesicoureteric reflux.

Antibiotic prophylaxis and behavioral modification can be used for management. Surgical correction can be done laparoscopically or by the endoscopic route. It should be considered in cases of recurrent acute pyelonephritis despite antibiotic therapy and in the presence of surgically correctable malformations.

Other options:

Option A: A DMSA scan can be done to assess the degree of renal scarring. DMSA renal scan will show photopenic areas bilaterally indicating acute pyelonephritis and renal scarring.

Options B and D: An ultrasound and MRI are not required to diagnose vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed vasopressin. This drug has its maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.
